dt: {bc}to represent (something) as human {bc}to attribute human qualities to (something)

dt.t: Much as we try, we can't stop {wi}humanizing{/wi} our horses.

dt: {bc}to address or portray (someone) in a way that emphasizes that person's humanity or individuality

dt.t: My goal, long before my father ever became homeless, was to {wi}humanize{/wi} those who lived on the streets.

dt: {bc}to include or increase human interaction in (something, such as a process or place)

dt.t: [Stan] Lowe said he's proud of the increased use of alternative-dispute resolution for the type of complaint that can be informally resolved between an officer and a member of the public. … {ldquo}It {wi}humanizes{/wi} the experience from both perspectives. It really does repair a relationship, but you're doing it one relationship at a time.{rdquo}

dt: {bc}to adapt (something) to human nature or use

dt.t: In this period of rapid change, the city began putting money back into the neighborhood. Over time, there was a conscious effort to invest in {wi}humanizing{/wi} the landscape, including the reinstallation of the now-famous seven steel arches and street trees.
The fact is, cats play different predatory roles in different natural and {wi}humanized{/wi} landscapes.
Lincoln forged a new lean language to {wi}humanize{/wi} and redeem the first modern war.

dt: {bc}to cause (a nonhuman organism or one of its parts) to include components (such as cells, tissues, or genes) of human origin or to produce human substances or components (such as insulin)

dt.t: It's OK to mess with a creature's {ldquo}simple{rdquo} parts—the plumbing in its gut, let's say—but we're risking moral crisis when we start to {wi}humanize{/wi} its neural tissue.
But other forms of {wi}humanized{/wi} mice, such as mice engineered to have a human immune system, are routine laboratory animals that seem to occasion little angst.
These {ldquo}{wi}humanized{/wi}{rdquo} cells were then removed and cloned with tumor cells to make a cell line that produced pure human monoclonal antibodies, the researchers said.

dt: {bc}to modify (a nonhuman antibody) by genetic engineering to contain mainly human protein sequences

dt.t: {d_link|Monoclonals|monoclonal:2} are made by cultivating antibody-producing cells in the immune system of mice, extracting them from the animals' spleen, and then going through an elaborate process to {ldquo}{wi}humanize{/wi}{rdquo} the antibodies to avoid immune reactions in human patients.
We're using mice to make {wi}humanized{/wi} antibodies that produce cancer drugs.

shortdef: to represent (something) as human : to attribute human qualities to (something)
to address or portray (someone) in a way that emphasizes that person's humanity or individuality
to include or increase human interaction in (something, such as a process or place)
